Dear Megan Zambiasi:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 616-552-3662.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4127 Staff to resident ratio.
Section (4) When residents are asleep or otherwise outside of the
Description direct supervision of staff, staff shall perform variable
interval, eye-on checks of residents. The time between the
variable interval checks shall not exceed fifteen minutes.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation A few days prior, staff did not complete required 15-minute checks
on three youth. Checks were completed between 40 minutes to an
hour, leaving 9 observations omitted.
Investigation This complaint was transferred to DCWL and assigned on
10/25/2023.
I interviewed the complainant via telephone on 10/26/2023 who
reported no additional information.
I interviewed Consumer Rights Officers at the facility on
10/27/2023. Consumer Rights Officers reported Deroy has 2
wings and four bedrooms on each wing. There are currently four
youths placed at Deroy. Midnight shift staff are required to
complete at least 32 eye on checks from 11 pm-7 am in 15-minute
variable intervals. Staff are required to complete the midnight shift
security logs reflecting the eye-on checks in real time.
I interviewed Youth A at the facility on 10/27/2023. Youth A has
been at the facility for 10 days. Youth A reported observing staff
sitting in the hallway during midnight shift. She said staff don’t
always do 15 minutes checks and sometimes it’s over one hour.
She expressed no other concerns regarding staff or the facility.
I interviewed Youth B at the facility on 10/27/2023. Youth B has
been at facility for one week. She reported there is always a staff
member supervising. She has observed staff doing routine checks
at night, but she is not sure how often they do the checks.
I interviewed Staff 1 on 11/16/2023 at the facility. Staff 1 has been
working at the facility for one year as a direct care. Staff usually
works the afternoon shift in the ILS program, but she also
sometimes covers the midnight shift at Deroy Hall. She reported
completing eye-on checks on youth if they are in observation
(suicide watch), but did not have a clear understanding about the
required eye-on check not to exceed 15 minutes in variable
2

intervals while youths are in their bedrooms.
I interviewed Staff 2 on 11/16/2023 via telephone. Staff 2 has
been working at the facility for 3 months and works the midnight
shift. Staff 2 has completed all new hire training. She reported
during the midnight shift she completes eye-on check on the
youths every 15 minutes and documents the checks on the log
form.
I interviewed Staff 3 on 11/16/2023 via telephone. Staff 3 is a
Team Leader and has been working at the facility for 2 months.
She reported staff are required to complete eye-on check on the
youths during the midnight shift. She said all staff are aware the
checks need to be completed in variable intervals not to exceed
15 minutes. She denied being aware of staff not completing eye-
on checks.
Video Footage Reviewed:
I reviewed video footage of midnight shift (11 pm -7am) from the
following dates: 10/22/2023, 10/23/2023, and 10/27/20239 (video
has no audio). Staff were observed not making eyes on checks in
varying intervals not to exceed 15 minutes when youth were
outside of staff’s sight. During review of the video footage the
following was observed while youth were in their bedrooms:
• On 10/22/2023, orange wing, Staff 1 comes on shift at
11pm Staff 1 completes four eye on checks from 11 pm till
7 am. There were no youth awake and moving around during
these times.
• On 10/23/2023, orange wing, Staff 2 comes on shift at 12
am. Staff 2 completes 10 eye-on checks from 11 pm till 7
am. There were no youth awake and moving around during
these times.
• On 10/27/2023, orang wing, Staff 3 comes on shift at 12
am. Staff 3 completes 22 eye on checks from 11 pm to 7
am. There were no youth awake and moving around during
these times.
Documents Reviewed:
• Facility policy for staff to client ratio, dated March 2021.
Sleeping hours staff to client ration is 1:10.
• Facility policy for client observation dated March 2021.
Clients on all units are to be continually supervised. Staff
members who are responsible for client supervision should
maintain line of sight management of those clients at all
times. The supervisor or team leader will complete the
3

appropriate sections of afternoon and midnight shift
security checklist form.
• Midnight shift log dated 10/22/2023, 10/23/2023,
10/24/2023, 10/25/2023, Orange Wing. Log form has time
preprinted starting at 11:15, 11:30, 11:45, 12:00,
12:15…..7:00 am. Staff enter their initials next to each time
slot indicating they made the eye-on check every 15
minutes starting at 11 pm through 7 am. Forms indicate
staff complete a total of 32 eye-on checks for each date.
The notes listed the number of youth in room, and no
issues.
• Youth A’s safety plan-crisis prevention plan noted problem
behaviors as feeling suicidal and threatening others.
Interventions were talking to an adult, time out in room,
sitting with staff, deep breathing, speaking with therapist,
and snapping bubble wrap.
Analysis The facility is non-compliant in performing and documenting eye-
on checks of youth at variable intervals not to exceed 15 minutes.
Based on Staff interviews and video footage staff are not
completing eye-on checks of each youth at least every 15 minutes
at varying intervals.
Technical Assistance
It is recommended that a new form be developed for staff to
document the monitoring of youth while they are asleep or outside
the direct supervision of staff. The midnight shift log should not
have pre-printed times. Staff should be documenting the actual
time at which they conduct a check. This prevents documenting
checks that did not occur, documenting checks done at times they
were not actually completed, and better ensures checks are done
at variable intervals rather than giving the impression they are
required every 15 minutes. The agency will need to ensure staff
have clear understanding of the rules and agency policies for all
their programs.
Conclusion Repat Violation Established

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4112 Criminal history check, subject to
Section requirements; staff qualifications
Description (4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the
following:
(a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Midnight shift logs are not being completed in real time.
Investigation Video Footage Reviewed:
• I reviewed video footage of midnight shift (11 pm -7am)
from the following dates: 10/22/2023, 10/23/2023, and
10/27/20239 (video has no audio). Staff were observed not
making eyes on checks in varying intervals not to exceed
15 minutes when youth were outside of staff’s sight.
Documents Reviewed:
• Midnight shift log dated 10/22/2023, 10/23/2023,
10/24/2023, 10/25/2023, Orange Wing. Log form has time
preprinted starting at 11:15, 11:30, 11:45, 12:00,
12:15…..7:00 am. Staff enter their initials next to each time
slot indicating they made the eye-on check every 15
minutes starting at 11 pm through 7 am. Forms indicate
staff complete a total of 32 eye-on checks for each date.
The notes listed the number of youth in room, and no
issues.
• Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 3 personnel file. There are no
disciplinary actions for job performance.
Analysis Based on documentations, and video footage reviewed staff did
not complete the midnight shift logs in real time and documented
doing numerous room checks they did not actually do. Staff
reported they did not have a clear understanding of the
requirements for completing eyes on checks on youths every 15
minutes in variable intervals.
Conclusion Violation Established
5

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
